class_notes:
(Same as AMST 385 2, ANT 385 5)
This course will explore oral history as a field of theory and practice and equip you with the skills and experience to conduct and analyze oral history interviews. Centering the practices of storytelling and listening, we will approach oral history as a humanistic method of discovery. Students will investigate the intellectual foundations of oral history and how living memory and storytelling help to understand a phenomenon or experience. We will deconstruct oral history as a method of information gathering, including the ethics and practices required to plan, conduct, record, and transcribe oral interviews. Taking up a variety of themes, such as culture, identity, individual and collective remembering, to name a few, we will together explore how oral history offers a distinct and crucial approach to understanding the past, while developing skills for future research and professional pursuits.
